{{Infobox person |name = Isadora Bennett |image = [[File:Isadora Bennett.jpg]] |image_caption = Circa 1962 |birth_date = {{birth date|1900|7|21}} |birth_place = [[Canton, Missouri|Canton]], [[Missouri]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1980|2|8|1900|7|21}} |death_place = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |occupation = Publicity agent, theatre manager |spouse = [[Daniel Reed (actor)|Daniel Reed]] |children = {{plainlist| *[[Susan Reed (singer)|Susan Reed]] (singer) *Jared Reed (actor)}} }} '''Isadora Bennett''' (July 21, 1900 – February 8, 1980) was a publicity agent for modern dance theatre. Her work has been considered significant for establishing modern dance. Her clients included [[Martha Graham]], [[José Limón]], [[José Greco]], [[American Ballet Theatre]], [[Royal Danish Ballet]], [[Joffrey Ballet]].<ref name=nyt-obit>{{cite news|title=Isadora Bennett, 79, Publicist for Dance|work=New York Times|last=Anderson|first=Jack|date=February 10, 1980|page=40}}</ref><ref name=variety-obit>{{cite news|title=Obituaries: Isadora Bennett|work=Variety|date=February 27, 1980|page=54}}</ref><ref name=dancemag>{{cite journal|work=Dance Magazine|title=Dance Magazine's 1962 Awards|volume=37|issue=4|date=April 1963|page=30–3}}</ref>
==Biography==
Born to Clarence and Catherine Bennett, actors, she went with her parents on tour as a young child.<ref name=variety-obit/><ref name=dancemag/> At age 5, she moved in with an aunt in [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]], [[Illinois]]. She took an early interest in the literary life, and there she befriended [[Vachel Lindsay]] and [[Edgar Lee Masters]].<ref name=dancemag/> At age 14, she received a scholarship to the [[University of Chicago]]. In 1916, she became a reporter for the ''[[Chicago Daily News]]'', where she befriended [[Carl Sandburg]], then still a reporter. In 1918, she married [[Daniel Reed (actor)|Daniel Reed]] (but would keep her maiden name professionally).<ref name=nyt-obit/>
The Reeds moved to [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]], [[South Carolina]], and founded the Town Theatre. They would move around, settling permanently in New York City in 1936.
There she became a theatrical and dance publicity agent. In 1939, [[Martha Graham]] became her client, and would stay with Bennett until 1970. She became partners with theatrical agent [[Richard Pleasant]]. Together they would also manage [[McCarter Theatre]] in Princeton, and arranged to have Broadway bound shows premiere there.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ewing|first=Alex C.|title=Bravura! Lucia Chase and the American Ballet Theatre|page=53|year=2009|publisher=University Press of Florida}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|work=Princeton Alumni Weekly|title=Princeton Theatre|page=8|date=September 28, 1956|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LxJbAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA44&dq=%22isadora%20bennett%22&pg=PA44#v=onepage&q=%22isadora%20bennett%22&f=false}}</ref>
She published occasional essays on dance for the general public under the pseudonym Weylan Morgan.<ref name=nyt-obit/>
She retired in 1972.<ref name=nyt-obit/>
==Awards== * '''1962''', ''[[Dance Magazine]]'' Award (with [[Margot Fonteyn]] and [[Bob Fosse]])<ref name=dancemag/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Dance Magazine|title=Dance Magazine Awards|url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/DanceMagazineAwards_PastRecipients.pdf}} This list gives year award given. In 1963, it was called the 1962 award.</ref> * '''1973''', [[Capezio#Capezio Dance Award|Capezio Dance Award]] <ref>{{cite news|work=New York Times|title=Miss Bennett to Get Capezio Award|page=42|date=April 23, 1973}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Isadora Bennett gets dance award|work=Gadsen Times|page=42|date=June 17, 1973|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1891&dat=19730617&id=d7sfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=s9cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1979,2924109}}</ref>
